none of the option look correct to me.
I would pick D if interface was Eth1/2 . Hope there is no typo

choices.B: Add a route with the destination of 192.168.1.0/24 using interface Eth 1/3 with a next-hop of 192.168.1.10
choices.A: Add a route with the destination of 192.168.1.0/24 using interface Eth 1/2 with a next-hop of 172.16.1.2.
choices.C: Add a route with the destination of 192.168.1.0/24 using interface Eth 1/3 with a next-hop of 172.16.1.2.
choices.D: Add a route with the destination of 192.168.1.0/24 using interface Eth 1/3 with a next-hop of 192.168.1.254.

questions.question_text:
An administrator would like to use App-ID's deny action for an application and would like that action updated with dynamic updates as new content becomes available.
Which security policy action causes this?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
For clarification:
each app has its own defualt deny-action listed in the database. If the deny option is selected in the policy rue, then this default action will be used.
Answer C is correct
Simple answer, confusing question..

C is correct answer.

A drop is silent, you simply discard the packet and don't tell anyone about it. This is great for most siatuations as you don't generate more traffic on your network and outsiders who may potentially be scanning you are non the wiser.

A deny sends a notification to the sender that something happened and their packet was rejected

questions.question_text: Selecting the option to revert firewall changes will replace what settings?

choices.C: the running configuration with settings from the candidate configuration
choices.D: the device state with settings from another configuration
choices.A: the candidate configuration with settings from the running configuration

discussion.content:
Correct answer should be A.
https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/pan-os/10-1/pan-os-web-interface-help/web-interface-basics/revert-changes

Selecting the option to revert firewall changes in Palo Altoâ€™s PAN-OS will replace the candidate configuration with settings from the running configuration123. This operation undoes changes you made to the candidate configuration since the last commit1. So, the correct answer is A. the candidate configuration with settings from the running configuration

D is correct 

The question does not specify the type of revert mode. 
Therefore, the answer cannot be specific, but a more general one!

Selected Answer: A
Revert operations replace settings in the current candidate configuration with settings from another configuration. Reverting changes is useful when you want to undo changes to multiple settings as a single operation instead of manually reconfiguring each setting.

Agree.
Select ConfigRevert Changes at the top right of the firewall or Panorama web interface to undo changes made to the candidate configuration since the last commit.
